DataElement.preferredName: ERCC1 Gene Protein Expression Stratification Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The stratification code for the transcription of a gene involved in nucleotide excision repair into a message and the subsequent translation into a functional protein.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The transcription of a gene involved in nucleotide excision repair into a message and the subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in nucleotide excision repair.:Any of a group of complex organic macromolecules that contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and usually sulfur and are composed of one or more chains of amino acids. Proteins are fundamental components of all living cells and include many substances, such as enzymes, hormones, and antibodies, that are necessary for the proper functioning of an organism.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in nucleotide excision repair.

A group of complex organic macromolecules composed of one or more chains (linear polymers) of alpha-L-amino acids linked by peptide bonds and ranging in size from a few thousand to over 1 million Daltons. Proteins are fundamental genetically encoded components of living cells with specific structures and functions dictated by amino acid sequence.

Property.preferredDefinition: The transcription of genetic information into a message and the subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A system of numbered categories for representation of data related to the process of classifying patients into strata as part of the randomization process or for purposes of data analysis; Based upon fundamental genetically encoded components of living cells with specific structures and functions dictated by amino acid sequence and typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High expression, greater than or equal to 1.7

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Any of a group of complex organic macromolecules that contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and usually sulfur and are composed of one or more chains of amino acids. Concepts.definition: A group of complex organic macromolecules composed of one or more chains (linear polymers) of alpha-L-amino acids linked by peptide bonds and ranging in size from a few thousand to over 1 million Daltons. Proteins are fundamental genetically encoded components of living cells with specific structures and functions dictated by amino acid sequence.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.
The process of classifying patients into a sequence of grades or ranks as part of the randomization process or for purposes of data analysis.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
